ARTICLE II. LAKE FORT PHANTOM HILL
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 15-17. High water line.
The high water line of Lake Fort Phantom Hill is hereby designated as the uncontrolled spillway elevation of one thousand six hundred
thirty-five and nine-tenths (1,635.9) feet above mean sea level enclosing that lake.
(Code 1965, § 20-10; Ord. No.16-2017, pt. 1(Exh. A-1), 6-8-17)
Sec. 15-18. Prohibited areas.
(a) A prohibited area is hereby established surrounding the water intake pump station on the east shore of Lake Fort Phantom Hill,
within a two hundred (200) foot radius of the pump station. Boating, skiing, swimming, or any other activity is hereby prohibited within
the buoys marking the boundary of this area. However, persons owning or leasing property along the shoreline of which is within the two
hundred (200) foot area shall be allowed to operate a boat at a speed which produces no white wake from their property to the nearest
point outside the prohibited area, and return only.
(b) A prohibited area is hereby designated within a fifty (50) foot radius of the control tower located near the east end of the dam at
Lake Fort Phantom Hill. No boating, skiing, swimming, or any other activity is allowed in the prohibited area.
(c) A prohibited area is hereby designated within a one hundred (100) foot radius of the indirect reuse discharge point structure (Outfall
003) located near the shoreline south of the east boat ramp (marked with a buoy).
(Code 1965, § 20-19; Ord. No. 62-2016, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-1-16; Ord. No. 16-2017, pt. 1(Exh. A-1), 6-8-17)
Sec. 15-19. Reserved.
Editor's note: Part 1 of Ordinance 23-1994, adopted May 26, 1994, repealed § 15-19 in its entirety. Formerly, § 15-19 pertained to speed of boats and derived from §
20-19 of the 1965 Code.
Sec. 15-20. Swimming areas.
(a) Any public swimming areas shall be approved by city council and clearly designated as such.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a water vessel within, or otherwise allow any water vessel to enter, any approved and
clearly marked swimming area.
(Code 1965, § 20-19; Ord. No. 23-1994, pt. 1, 5-26-94)
Sec. 15-20.1. Placing motor vehicles or other obstructions upon Lake Fort Phantom Hill prohibited.
No person shall drive, park or otherwise place a motor vehicle, nor place any other obstruction, upon the bed of Lake Fort Phantom Hill,
or within the high water line of said lake.
Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the operation of boats upon the waters of said lake, nor the launching of boats at
boat launching ramps at said lake through the use of a motor vehicle or through the use of other lawful means.
(Ord. No. 22-1980, pt. 1, 3-27-80; Ord. No. 1-2001, pt. 1(Exh. A), 1-11-01)
Editor's note: Part 1 of Ordinance 22-1980, enacted March 27, 1980, amended the 1965 Code with the addition of a new § 20-24. Said provisions have been
codified as § 15-20.1 of this Code at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 15-21. Reserved.
Editor's note: Part 1 of Ordinance 23-1994, adopted May 26, 1994, repealed § 15-21 in its entirety. Formerly, § 15-21 pertained to unattended vehicles in public boat
ramps and derived from § 20-24.1 of the 1965 Code.
Sec. 15-22. Lot leases to be subject to article.

DIVISION 2. CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS*
Sec. 15-31. Lot locations and restrictions.
The contour map containing the lot numbers and location of the lots along the banks of Lake Fort Phantom Hill as the same appears in the
office of the city secretary is referred to and made a part of this article for all purposes, and the designation of the use of lots as provided
thereon is a part of this article. No building permit will be issued for the erection of any structure other than in compliance with such lot
designations; where any lot is restricted as to a particular use, such use restriction shall be fully complied with.
(Code 1965, § 20-16)
Sec. 15-32. Building permit–Required.
No person shall erect or structurally alter any pier, dock, wharf, float island or other structure or do any plumbing or electrical work
thereon in Lake Fort Phantom Hill or along the shores of such lake without first having applied for and obtained a permit for such
construction or alteration from the building official of the city.
(Code 1965, § 20-11)
Sec. 15-33. Same–Application; plans and specifications.
Every application for a permit to erect or structurally alter any pier, dock, wharf, float island, building or other structure or to do any
plumbing or electrical work thereon in or along the shore of Lake Fort Phantom Hill shall be accompanied by a plot plan showing the
proposed layout of such structural alteration, together with a legal description of the property on which the proposed new construction or
alterations are to be made. Designation by lot number as assigned by the city shall be a sufficient legal description.
(Code 1965, § 20-12)
Sec. 15-34. Same–Approval of electrical plans and work required.
Prior to the issuance of any permit for the building, construction or alteration of any structure in or on the shores of Lake Fort Phantom
Hill there shall be submitted to the building official a plan outline of the wiring to be used in such structure and the same shall first be
approved as to its safety for the intended use before the issuance of any building permit shall be authorized. No electrical service wires
shall be attached to any building until the same has been inspected and passed by the building inspection department.
(Code 1965, § 20-13)
Sec. 15-35. Same–Compliance with division.
No building permit shall be issued under the provisions of this division unless the proposed construction or alteration shall be in
compliance with the provisions of this division.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-36. Reserved.
Editor's note: Part 1 of Ordinance 23-1994, adopted May 26, 1994, repealed § 15-36 in its entirety. Formerly, § 15-36 pertained to building permit and appeal of
decision of building official and derived from § 20-15 of the 1965 Code.
Sec. 15-37. Location of structures generally.
Any structure erected or structurally altered in or along the shoreline of Lake Fort Phantom Hill, including residential and commercial
structures, but excluding boat houses, docks and other nonresidence structures which must have water contact, shall be situated so that the
floor of such building shall be [as shown on] the FIRM maps plus one foot and alterations shall be allowed as per the zoning ordinance
and building codes.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 111/648
(Code 1965, § 20-14; Ord. No. 88-1982, pt. 1, 7-8-82)
Sec. 15-38. Location of certain businesses restricted.
No business such as a restaurant, dance hall, concession stand or any other enterprise for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise,
except marine supplies and tackle, shall be erected on any pier, dock, wharf, float island, piling or other structure extending into or above
Lake Fort Phantom Hill.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-39. Extension into lake restricted.
No structure shall be erected in any part of Lake Fort Phantom Hill or any channel or arm thereof so as to extend a distance of more than
two hundred (200) feet into the lake or channel or arm thereof, or a distance of more than one-third the distance from shore to shore of
such lake, arm or channel at the point where the structure is erected, whichever shall be the lesser distance. Such distance shall be
measured from the high water line.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-40. Proximity to property line.
No structure shall be erected nor structurally altered to be nearer than five (5) feet to any property line of the owner or applicant.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-41. Resistance to wind, water pressures.
Construction of any piers, wharves, floats or docks shall be well braced to withstand the pressure of wind and water with boats tied to
such pier, dock, wharf, float or other structure.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-42. Metal barrels, drums prohibited.
In no event shall metal barrels or oil drums be used in the installation, repair or remodeling of a pier or dock. The property owner or
lessee shall maintain all piers and docks in a safe condition for their intended use at all times.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-43. Septic tanks restricted.
No existing septic tanks or drain lines shall be permitted either below elevation 1642.0 mean sea level or within twenty-five (25) feet
horizontally of the elevation 1635.9 mean sea level (uncontrolled spillway elevation) contour line and no new septic tanks or new or
additional drain lines shall be installed closer than seventy-five (75) feet of elevation 1635.9 feet mean sea level; provided that any septic
tank or drain line existing on July 1, 1977, that does not meet these requirements but is in use at such time may continue to be used and
maintained contingent upon proper maintenance as determined by periodic inspection and subject to all existing and future federal, state
and city rules, regulations, laws and ordinances.
(Code 1965, § 20-14; Ord. No. 16-2017, pt. 1(Exh. A-1), 6-8-17)
Sec. 15-44. Inspections.
All piers, wharves, floats and docks shall be inspected by the lake patrol officers during the month of July of each year.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-45. Notice of noncompliance.
The owner or lessee of the property on which a structure is situated at Lake Fort Phantom Hill shall be notified in writing if such structure
does not meet the provisions of this division.
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Sec. 15-46. Compliance with notice.
If a structure at Lake Fort Phantom Hill does not meet the provisions of this division, repair or alteration shall be required at the owner's
or lessee's expense to bring such structure into compliance with this division within thirty (30) days of receipt of notice of
noncompliance.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 112/648
(Code 1965, § 20-14)
Secs. 15-47–15-53. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. RECREATIONAL ACTIVITY
Sec. 15-54. Definition.
For the purposes of this division, the term “recreational activity” shall mean and include any water carnival, power boat race, sailboat
race, trade show, water skiing competition or exhibition or any other such activity at Lake Fort Phantom Hill or on the lake shore.
(code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-55. Agreement, permit required.
No person shall conduct any recreational activity at the lake or lake shore without having entered into a recreational activity agreement
with the director of water utilities or his designated representative. This agreement shall constitute a permit for the requesting
organization to hold such activity.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-56. Compliance with agreement.
No person shall conduct any recreational activity in violation of any term or condition specified in the agreement therefor.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-57. Application for agreement.
The person or entity proposing to hold a recreational activity shall make application to the director of water utilities for an agreement for
such program or event. Such application shall be signed by the person or entity making application and shall state all details of the
proposed program or event. All applications shall be in writing and shall be submitted thirty (30) days in advance of the planned activity.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-58. Fee.
The fee for any permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each recreational activity.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-59. Insurance.
The applicant for an agreement permit required by the provisions of this division shall obtain insurance in at least an amount meeting the
requirements of the state torts claim act; and shall furnish a certificate of such insurance before the permit shall be issued. The city shall
be named in such insurance policy as an additional insured.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Sec. 15-60. Rescission.
The director of water utilities or his designated representative shall have the right to rescind any permit granted under this division and to
require the removal of any and all equipment to be used by the applicant, upon his failure to comply with the terms and conditions in this
chapter or in the recreational activity agreement, or if weather conditions or some other conditions should arise which would require that
activity not be permitted at the lake because the public safety would be jeopardized by such recreational activity.
(Code 1965, § 20-23)
Secs. 15-61–15-71. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. LAKE ABILENE, LAKE KIRBY, CAMERON LAKE, AND NELSON PARK LAKE
Sec. 15-72. Reserved.
Editor's note–Former section 15-72 pertaining to enforcement, was deleted in its entirety by Ord. No. 16-2017 adopted 6-8-17. Prior to the deletion this section
derived from the following: Code 1965, § 20-32; Ord. No. 29-2012, pt. 1, 6-28-12; and Ord. No. 62-2016, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-1-16.
Sec. 15-73. Prohibited activities, areas.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 113/648
(a) No person shall operate a personal water vessel, watercraft or surf craft in the waters of Lake Abilene at a distance of less than two
hundred (200) feet from the water intake.
(b) Swimming is prohibited in all areas of Lake Kirby and Nelson Park Lake.
(c) Operation of personal water vessels, is prohibited at Lake Abilene, Cameron Lake, and Nelson Park Lake. Personal water vessel
means a motorized vessel that is specifically designed to be operated by a person or persons sitting, standing, or kneeling on the vessel or
in the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel.
(d) No person shall drive, park or otherwise place a motor vehicle, motorcycle, dirt bike, 4-wheeler or other wheeled-recreational
vehicle, nor place any other obstruction, upon the bed of Lake Abilene, Lake Kirby, Cameron Lake or Nelson Park Lake.
(e) Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting any use authorized by the city or the operation of water vessels (other than
those listed in subsections (c) or (f)) upon the waters of said lakes nor the launching of water vessels at launching ramps at said lakes
through the use of a motor vehicle or through the use of other lawful means.
(f) Operation of wind craft and surf craft is prohibited at Nelson Park Lake. Wind craft and surf craft means nonmotorized canoes,
punts, rowboats, sailboats, rubber rafts, racing shells, rowing sculls, kayaks, and other paddle craft when paddled, poled, oared, or
windblown. The Abilene Zoo shall have authority to operate wind craft and surf craft on Nelson Park Lake.
(g) A prohibited area is hereby designated within a one hundred (100) foot radius of the outlet control tower located near the east end
of the dam at Lake Kirby.
(Code 1965, § 20-28; Ord. No. 23-1994, pt. 1, 5-26-94; Ord. No. 1-2001, pt. 2(Exh. A), 1-11-01; Ord. No. 29-2012, pt. 1, 6-28-12; Ord.
No. 62-2016, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-1-16; Ord. No. 16-2017, pt. 1(Exh. A-1), 6-8-17)
Sec. 15-74. Reserved.
Editor's note–Former section 15-74 pertaining to fishing regulations and deriving from the 1965 Code, § 20-26 and Ordinance 29-2012, pt. 1, adopted 6-28-12; was
deleted in its entirety by Ordinance 62-2016, pt. 1(Exh. A), adopted 12-1-16.
Sec. 15-75. Lake Abilene hours of operation.
Lake Abilene shall be closed to all recreational uses including but not limited to swimming, boating, or camping, between sunset of one
day and sunrise of the following day except by special permission from the director of water utilities.
(Code 1965, § 20-27; Ord. No. 23-1994, pt. 1, 5-26-94; Ord. No. 29-2012, pt. 1, 6-28-12; Ord. No. 62-2016, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-1-16)
Sec. 15-76. Swimming at Lake Abilene
Swimming shall be permitted in certain areas of Lake Abilene only as authorized by the director of the water utilities or designated entity.
(Ord. No. 29-2012, pt. 1, 6-28-12)

Chapter 16
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 16-1. Definitions.
For the purposes of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
Massage: Any process containing of kneading, rubbing or otherwise manipulating the skin of the body of a human being, either with the
hand or by means of electrical instruments or apparatus, or other special apparatus, but shall not include massage by duly licensed
physicians, nor massage of the face practiced by duly licensed beauty parlors or barbershops.
Massage establishment: Any building, room, place or establishment other than regularly licensed hospitals where manipulated massage or
manipulated exercises are practiced upon the human body by anyone not a duly licensed physician, whether with or without use of
mechanical, therapeutic or bathing devices, and shall include Turkish bathhouses or any other establishment being operated as a business.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 114/648
This term shall not include, however, beauty parlors or barbershops duly licensed under the penal code of the state or registered physical
therapists who treat only patients recommended by a licensed physician and who operate only under such physician's direction.
(Code 1965, § 8-46)
Sec. 16-2. Right of inspection; interference with inspectors.
The officers of the police and health departments of the city are hereby authorized and empowered to enter, for the purpose of inspection,
and to inspect at any time massage establishments in the city, for the preservation of law and order and decency and further empowered
to, at any time, make such examinations through the licensed physicians of the department of health of the city as are necessary to
determine whether or not such employees are infected with any infectious disease.
It shall be grounds for the revocation of licenses issued under this chapter to interfere with the inspection of such premises.
(Code 1965, § 8-57)
Sec. 16-3. Hours of operation.
No massage establishment shall be kept open for any purpose between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.
(Code 1965, § 8-56)
Sec. 16-4. Living, sleeping quarters prohibited.
No massage establishment shall be operated or conducted in connection with any place used for living or sleeping quarters.
(Code 1965, § 8-56)
Sec. 16-5. List of employees.
The manager or person in charge of massage establishments shall keep a list of the names and addresses of all employees, both on duty
and off duty, and such list shall be shown to all proper authorities of the police and health departments upon request.
(Code 1965, § 8-60)
Sec. 16-6. Sanitary requirements.
It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a massage establishment to keep the same at all times in a clean and sanitary
condition. All instruments and mechanical, therapeutic and bathing devices or parts thereof that come into contact with the human body
shall be sanitized by a modern and approved method of sanitization before initial use, and any such instruments and devices or parts
thereof after having been used upon one patron shall be sanitized before being used on another. All towels and linens furnished for use of
one patron shall not be furnished for use of another until thoroughly laundered.
(Code 1965, § 8-62)
Secs. 16-7–16-17. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. LICENSE
Sec. 16-18. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a massage establishment without first having obtained a license therefor from the city
secretary, in accordance with the provisions of this article.
(Code 1965, § 8-47)
Sec. 16-19. Investigation of applicant.
After an application has been made for an original license or a renewal of an existing license to operate a massage establishment, the chief
of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant's character and whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any
crime involving moral turpitude in any state, municipal or federal court, or whether the applicant is a person of unfit character, or whether
the holder of a license for such an establishment, or any employee of such establishment committed any lewd, indecent or other act
contrary to common decency during the last licensing period, or such an establishment employs any person convicted of any crime
involving moral turpitude in any state, municipal or federal court, or whether such an establishment employs a woman who has been
convicted of vagrancy or prostitution, or who is a known prostitute.
(Code 1965, § 8-49)
Sec. 16-20. Names of, medical certificates for employees.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 115/648
At the time of making application for the license required by this article, the applicant shall furnish to the health department of the city the
names and addresses of all employees of massage establishments and all such employees of massage establishments shall be required to
secure from the health department a medical certificate certifying that such employee has been examined and that such examination
discloses the fact that such person employed, or to be employed by such establishment, is free from any infectious or communicable
disease. Such medical certificate shall be renewed annually by the health officer.
(Code 1965, § 8-50)
Sec. 16-21. Fee.
The fees and charges for services furnished by the city, shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
secretary.
(Code 1965, § 8-51; Ord. No. 65-1986, pt. 1, 8-28-86)
Sec. 16-22. Issuance restricted.
A massage establishment license shall only be issued upon the approval of the health officer and the chief of police, in writing, and a
certificate of occupancy from the building inspector.
(Code 1965, § 8-47)
Sec. 16-23. Refusal–Authorized.
The chief of police shall refuse to approve the issuance or renewal of any license required by this article to any applicant who has been
convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any state, municipal or federal court, or where the applicant is a person of unfit
character, or where the holder of a license for such an establishment or any employee of such an establishment committed any lewd,
indecent or other act contrary to common decency during the last licensing period; or where any such establishment employs any person
convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any state, municipal or federal court, or which employs a woman who has been
convicted of vagrancy or prostitution, or who is a known prostitute.
(Code 1965, § 8-52)
Sec. 16-24. Same–Appeal.
In the event the chief of police shall refuse to approve the issuance of an original license or the renewal of a license to any applicant in
this article, the action of the chief of police shall be final unless the applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal to approve the
issuance of or the renewal of a license, file a written appeal with the city secretary, addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing by
the city upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted.
In the event such appeal is filed, the chief of police shall provide the city council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with
reference to the application in question, including the written application, together with the action of the chief of police and the reasons
for such action. The city council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the
chief of police, at which hearing the city council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether all the pertinent facts appear in
the application or not, and the city council shall determine whether or not such license shall be granted or refused, and such action as the
city council shall take thereon shall be final and conclusive.
(Code 1965, § 8-53)
Sec. 16-25. Display.
The license required by this article shall be exhibited at all times in the licensed establishments.
(Code 1965, § 8-48)
Sec. 16-26. Revocation–Authorized.
Any license issued by the city secretary, after approval in writing by the director of public health and the chief of police, pursuant to this
article, may be suspended or revoked by the chief of police when it shall appear that the business of the person to whom such permit was
issued has been conducted in a disorderly or improper manner, or in violation of any statute of the state, any applicable provision of this
Code or other ordinance of the city, or that the person conducting such business is of unfit character to conduct same, or that the purpose
for which such license has been issued is being abused, to the detriment of the public, or that the license is being used for a purpose
different from that for which it was issued to the license holder or that the establishment is not kept in a sanitary condition as determined
by the health officer. Such notice of revocation shall be given by the chief of police in writing and shall be addressed to the license
holder's last known business address.
(Code 1965, § 8-54)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 116/648
Sec. 16-27. Same–Appeal.
In the event the chief of police revokes the license issued to any license holder under this article, the action of the chief of police shall be
final unless the license holder shall, within ten (10) days after the receipt of written notice of such revocation, file a written appeal with
the city secretary addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing by the council upon the question as to whether or not such license
should have been revoked.
In the event such appeal is filed, the chief of police shall provide the city council with a record of all the proceedings theretofore had with
reference to the revocation of the license in question, together with the action of the chief of police and the reasons for such action. The
city council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the chief of police, at which
hearing the city council may make such investigation as it may see fit, and the city council shall determine whether or not the action of
the chief of police should be ratified and confirmed, or should be set aside, and such decision of the city council, after such hearing, shall
be final and conclusive as to all parties.
(Code 1965, § 8-55)
Chapter 17
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 17-1–17-50. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. PAWN SHOPS*
Sec. 17-51. Hold period for personal property purchased by pawn shops.
(a) Each item of personal property purchased from the general public by any local pawn shop under the regulation of the Texas Pawn
Shop Act and the Consumer Credit Commissioner must be held at the licensed pawn shop location for a period from the purchase date
before being modified, changed, sold, or disposed of in any manner for at least eleven (11) days.
(b) The city police department shall have the authority to extend the hold period on any particular personal property if the interest of
justice so requires, from eleven (11) days, to a period not exceeding twenty (20) days, by providing written notice to the local pawn shop,
(under the regulation of the Consumer Credit Commissioner,) in possession of the personal property on or before the 11th day of the hold
period.
(Ord. No. 16-2001, pts. 1, 2, 7-26-01; Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Secs. 17-52–17-60. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. METAL RECYCLING ENTITIES AND PRECIOUS METAL BUYERS
Sec. 17-61. Definitions.
The following words or phrases, whenever used in this article, shall be construed as defined in this section:
Business days. Every official working day of the week, including Monday through Friday. This shall exclude any day in which the city
administration offices are closed due to holidays, inclement weather days, etc.
Chief of police. The chief of police of the City of Abilene, Texas, or designated representative.
City secretary. The city secretary of the City of Abilene, Texas, or designated representative.
Consignment store. A retail store that sells secondhand items on behalf of others and receives a percentage of the sales price.
Fixed location. A location that is owned or leased solely as a storefront location to sell or purchase precious metals or regulated metals.
Metal recycling entity. Anyone who operates or maintains a scrap metal yard or other place in which used or previously purchased metal
items or scrap metal is collected or kept for shipment, sale, or transfer or engages in the business of utilizing machinery or equipment for
the processing of or manufacturing of iron, steel, or nonferrous metallic scrap and whose principal product is scrap iron, scrap steel or
nonferrous metallic scrap for re-melting purposes.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 117/648
Precious metal. Metals as defined by the Texas Occupations Code section 1956.051, as amended.
Precious metal buyer. Any person engaged in the business of buying gold, silver, platinum, palladium, iridium, rhodium, osmium,
ruthenium, or an alloy of those metals as defined in Texas Occupations Code section 1956.051, as amended.
Regulated metal. Metals as defined by the Texas Occupations Code section 1956.001, as amended.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-62. Exceptions.
This article shall not be applicable to:
(a) The sale of aluminum cans.
(b) Trade or purchase of firearms.
(c) Entities licensed as a pawn shop with the state.
(d) The sale or purchase of coins.
(e) Consignment stores with the exception of transactions of precious metals.
(f) Secondhand personal property businesses with the exception of transactions of precious metals.
(g) Items purchased at auctions or estate sales.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-63. Permit required.
All persons transacting business as a metal recycling entity or a precious metal buyer shall have a current metal and precious metal permit
to operate issued by the city.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-64. Permit application.
Applicants for permits under this article must file with the city secretary an application in writing on a form obtained from the city
secretary and provide the following:
(a) A valid Texas Driver's License or state-issued photo identification.
(b) A valid email address.
(c) The number of the limited sales tax permit issued to the business by the state comptroller's office, if applicable.
(d) A brief description of the activity or business to be conducted.
(e) The appropriate fee.
Any application made pursuant to the provisions of this article may be presented to the Better Business Bureau of Abilene or the city
police department for investigation.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-65. Required fee.
The fees and charges for permits furnished by the city shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
secretary. No application for a permit will be processed until the required fees are tendered to the city secretary. Permit fees are
nonrefundable and shall not be prorated.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-66. Issuance.
Upon completion and presentation of the application, the city secretary shall issue a permit to the applicant within 5 business days unless
grounds for denial exist under section 17-70 of this article.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 118/648
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-67. Contents.
(a) Each permit issued under this article shall show the name of the permitted individual, business address, the date of issuance, and the
expiration date of such permit.
(b) The permit shall be numbered and printed in black; except, that the following shall be printed prominently thereon in red: “The
issuance of this license is not an endorsement by the City of Abilene, or any of its officers or employees, and expires _____________.”
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-68. Permit expiration.
The permit will be valid through December 31 of the year the permit is issued. The permit will only be valid for the address for which it
is issued and will become void if the location of the business is changed.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-69. Transfer.
No permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferred or assigned to any person or business entity.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-70. Denial.
An application for permit may be denied to a person under this article for the following reasons:
(a) An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application.
(b) Permit for same business has been revoked within the past 6 months.
(c) The applicant has been convicted within the previous five years of felony offense under chapters 30 through 32 of the
Texas Penal Code as amended and is not clear of community supervision or parole for the last five years.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-71. Revocation.
(a) Permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked for any of the following causes by any official of the city:
(1) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit.
(2) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business.
(3) Any violation of this article.
(4) Applicant is convicted of a felony offense under chapters 30 through 32 of the Texas Penal Code, as amended.
(b) Notice of revocation of a permit shall be given in writing, and specify the grounds of the revocation.
(c) When notice is received that a permit has been revoked, the person shall immediately surrender their permit to the revoking official
and the business operations governed by the permit shall cease to operate.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-72. Appeals.
(a) An appeal from any act of denial or revocation of any permit shall be filed with the city manager or his designee within five (5)
business days from the date of denial or revocation.
(b) Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city manager or his designee a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the
appeal.
(c) The city manager or his designee shall issue a decision on the denial or revocation in writing within 5 business days of receipt of the
appeal.
(d) The revocation or denial is not stayed pending the city manager's or his designee's decision.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 119/648
(e) The decision and order of the city manager or his designee on such appeal shall be final and conclusive.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-73. Exhibition of permit required.
All persons transacting business as a metal recycling entity or precious metal buyer shall conspicuously display the current permit to
operate issued by the city.
“Conspicuously displayed” shall mean displayed so that it is visible to any customer conducting business with the metal recycling entity
or precious metal buyer.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-74. Recordkeeping requirements.
(a) Except as otherwise provided herein, every person licensed or transacting any business as a metal recycling entity or precious metal
buyer within the city shall use the entity designated by the chief of police to maintain an electronic inventory-tracking system and
transmit all information required by this article via computer to the entity designated by the chief of police.
(b) The information required to be transmitted by this section must include:
(1) The date and time of each transaction in which precious metal or regulated metal is purchased, pledged, or received
monetary value for said item(s).
(2) An accurate and detailed description of any and all precious metal or regulated metal purchased or acquired during the
regular course of business for any monetary value, including any and all trademarks, identification numbers, serial numbers,
model numbers, brand names, and other identifying marks.
(3) The full name, address, date of birth, driver's license number or state-issued identification card, and physical description
of the person with whom each such purchase or transaction is consummated. The person must present their driver's license or
state-issued identification card to vendor at the time of each transaction.
(4) A digital photograph is required of any precious metal or regulated metal purchased by a precious metal buyer or metal
recycling entity acquired during the course of business. This digital photograph shall be uploaded to the entity designated by
the chief of police which will be associated with the transaction. Photographs shall clearly depict the item(s). No more than
(10) ten pieces of precious metal may be photographed together. They must be photographed in a manner in which they can
easily be identified
(c) The information required to be transmitted by subsection (b) of this section shall be transmitted within 24 hours of the transaction.
(d) Failure to obtain such information or to falsify such information may result in a citation issued to the individual completing the
transaction or the on-site manager or supervisor.
(e) Exception to photograph requirements. Metal recycling entities with a fixed location shall not be required to photograph and upload
their purchases if they have a digital video recorder that captures day-to-day activities and transaction within the business that will be
made available within three business days upon request of the chief of police. If the entities do not have a DVR system they will be
required to photograph and upload each regulated metal transaction. Video evidence will be retained 90 days; photographs will be
retained 180 days.
(f) Exception to reporting requirements. The exceptions found in section 1956.002 of the Texas Occupations Code, as amended, shall
apply to this section provided any payment made for the regulated materials excepted under this section is paid to the utility or business
and not to an individual seller. The excepted transactions include:
(1) A purchase of regulated material from a public utility or a manufacturing, industrial, commercial, retail, or other seller
that sells regulated material in the ordinary course of the seller's business;
(2) A purchase of regulated material by a manufacturer whose primary business is the manufacture of iron and steel
products made from melting scrap iron and scrap steel; or
(3) The transport or hauling of recyclable materials to or from the metal recycling entity.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-75. Police hold binder required.
(a) All metal recycling entities or precious metal buyers within the city shall maintain a police hold binder to log all property believed
to be stolen or that is under investigation.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 120/648
(b) This binder shall consist of a three ring notebook containing a current copy of this article, a property log on a form approved by the
city police department, and signed statements from each employee acknowledging they have been provided a copy of this article and they
understand the provisions.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-76. Stolen property or property under investigation.
(a) Any item deemed as stolen property or under law enforcement investigation shall be placed away from public view, shall be moved
separate from other purchased items and identified as “police hold” item(s) and shall be noted in the police hold binder provided by the
city police department. Pursuant to the Texas Occupations Code section 1956.037, property subject to “police hold” shall be held a
minimum of 60 days unless directed otherwise by a peace officer.
(b) Any law enforcement agency other than the city police department that requests items to be placed on hold due to an ongoing
investigation shall be directed to the city police department's criminal investigations division upon placing said item on police hold.
(c) Property subject to “police hold” shall be held a minimum of 60 days. Property may be released before the expiration of 60 days if
directed by a peace officer.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-77. Acceptance of government or utility property by a metal recycling entity.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person licensed or transacting any business as a metal recycling entity within the city to purchase or
receive any item of property on which words or markings appear indicating ownership of such item by any government entity or any
public utility company, except where the person offering such item for sale or transfer provides:
(1) Written authorization from the governmental entity, or utility to convey the item on behalf of the entity or utility; or
(2) A valid receipt from the governmental entity or utility evidencing such entity or utility has conveyed or relinquished
ownership of the item.
(b) It shall not be a defense to prosecution that an item of property contains no words or markings indicating ownership if the person
who purchased or received the item knows or should reasonably be expected to know such item is owned by any government entity or
any public utility company.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-78. Acceptance of property sealed or unopened in its original packaging by a metal recycling entity.
It shall be unlawful for any person licensed or transacting any business as a metal recycling entity within the city to purchase or receive
an item of property sealed or unopened in its original packaging unless the person conveying such item presents a receipt or proof of
purchase for the item. Evidence of ownership must be retained with the item.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-79. Acceptance of property inscribed with a company name by a metal recycling entity.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person licensed or transacting any business as a metal recycling entity within the city limits to purchase
or receive an item of property identified as the property of a business entity unless the person conveying such item provides at the time of
conveyance a valid receipt indicating lawful ownership, a signed statement attesting to lawful ownership, or written authorization from
the owner to convey the item on such owner's behalf.
(b) Evidence of ownership or written authorization to convey the item must be retained with the item, unless otherwise authorized by
the chief of police.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-80. Hold period for personal property.
Each item of precious metal purchased from the general public by any precious metal buyer must be held at the dealer's location for a
period from the purchase date before being modified, changed, sold, or disposed of in any manner for at least seven (7) days. Exceptions
can be granted by the chief of police for unique circumstances.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-81. Hold period for personal property for metal recycling entities.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 121/648
Section 17-80 of this article does not apply to metal recycling entities. Those entities shall hold all personal property for the time period
required by state law.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-82. Extension of hold period.
The chief of police shall have the authority to extend the hold period on any particular personal property if the interest of justice so
requires by providing written notice to the precious metal buyer or metal recycling entity in possession of the personal property on or
before the expiration of the hold period.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-83. Additional requirements for precious metal buyers without a fixed location.
In addition to the other requirements of this article any precious metal buyer without a fixed location operating in the city shall make all
purchases available for inspection at request of the chief of police within three (3) business days. This request can be either by phone,
email or fax.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-84. Enforcement; inspections; access to records.
The chief of police shall have the authority, in accordance with applicable law, to do the following to enforce the provisions of this article:
(a) Issue any orders, directives, or warnings required to carry out the intent and purpose of this article and its particular
provisions.
(b) Enter and inspect any premises covered by the provisions of this article to determine compliance with the provisions of
this article and all applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards or directives of the state.
(c) Request and receive any records necessary to establish the premises are covered by a valid permit.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Sec. 17-85. Penalty.
(a) A violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each transaction and each day shall be considered a separate offense.
(b) Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any
violation of this article, including seizure of goods.
(Ord. No. 58-2012, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-6-12)
Chapter 18
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC*
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. Definitions.
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
Alley: Any street as herein defined having no legal or official name other than alley.
Curb: The edge of the roadway marked or understood.
Double parking: The parking of a vehicle on the roadway or a portion thereof alongside any vehicle which is parallel parked, or behind
any vehicle which is parked head in.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 122/648
Legal holiday: Only the following days: January 1 (New Year's Day); Fourth Monday in May (Memorial Day); July 4 (Independence
Day); First Monday in September (Labor Day); Fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving Day); and December 25 (Christmas Day).
Loading zones: Spaces adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading and unloading of freight or passengers.
Parkway: That portion of a street or highway between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines not
intended for use of pedestrians; also, the intervening space between the roadways of a divided street or highway, or any island or area,
whether or not clearly defined by curbs or markings which divides any portion of any street, highway or intersection into separate lanes
for vehicular traffic.
School day: Any day officially designated by appropriate public school district trustees as a day on which school will be in session.
In addition to the foregoing definitions, this chapter hereby adopts all of the definitions of the state law as set out in Article 6701d,
Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes, as presently enacted or subsequently amended, provided, that in the event of any conflict, the
foregoing definitions shall control. All other words used in this chapter shall have their ordinary and commonly accepted meanings.
(Code 1965, § 17-1; Ord. No. 23-1985, pt. 1, 3-28-85)
Sec. 18-2. State law adopted.
There is adopted as a part of this chapter all of the provisions of Article 6701d of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes insofar as applicable.
(Code 1965, § 17-7)
Sec. 18-3. Use of roadway by persons on roller skates, etc.
No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway designated
as a “through street” except while crossing such street on a crosswalk and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights
and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply to persons using or riding a scooter or
bicycle as authorized by chapter 23, scooter and bicycle sharing.
(Code 1965, § 17-10; Ord. No. 20-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 4-11-19)
Sec. 18-4. When driver unable to report accidents.
Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of giving immediate notice of an accident and there was another occupant in the
vehicle at the time of the accident capable of doing so, such occupant, shall give, or cause to be given, the notice not given by the driver.
(Code 1965, § 17-18)
Sec. 18-5. Boarding or alighting from vehicles.
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion.
(Code 1965, § 17-69)
Sec. 18-6. Unlawful riding.
No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not
apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for
merchandise.
(Code 1965, § 17-70)
Sec. 18-7. Railroad trains not to block streets.
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a
manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five (5) minutes, except that this
provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion other than those engaged in switching.
(Code 1965, § 17-71)
Sec. 18-8. Mufflers required.
(a) No person shall operate a motorcycle, motorscooter, mini-bike or motor driven bicycle on private or public property, unless such
vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying
smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cut-out, by-pass or similar device.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 123/648
(b) The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate this
section.
(Code 1965, § 19-23)
State law references: Mufflers, Vernon's Civ. Sts., art. 6701d, § 134.
Sec. 18-9. Operation of noisy vehicles.
(a) The running of any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle in such a manner as to create loud or unnecessary noise is hereby
declared to be unlawful and is hereby prohibited.
(b) The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate this
section.
(Code 1965, § 19-23)
Sec. 18-10. Roller skates, bicycles and similar devices prohibited within certain district; exception.
(a) No person shall use or operate roller skates, rollerblades, or skateboards, or ride in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar
device, upon any public roadway, sidewalk, walkway or other public areas within the district designated and described under subsection
(c), unless specifically permitted and posted for such purposes.
(b) No person shall use or operate a bicycle, tricycle, unicycle or other similar device upon any sidewalk, walkway or other public
areas other than the public roadway within the district designated and described under subsection (c), unless specifically permitted and
posted for such purposes.
(c) The activities set forth in subsections (a) and (b) are prohibited within the area encompassed by the boundaries of the Abilene
Reinvestment Zone #1, commonly known as the tax increment financing district (TIF district).
The outside boundary streets are as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of Orange Street and N. 8th Street as the northwest corner then east along N. 8th Street to Plum
Street, then north to N. 10th Street, then east to N. Treadaway Boulevard, then south on N. Treadaway Boulevard to N. 3rd
Street, then east to Almond Street, then south and southwesterly to a point just north of the east-west Texas & Pacific Railroad
tracks on the northern projection of Rose Street, then south on Rose Street to S. 2nd Street, then west to Locust Street, then
south on Locust Street to S. 5th Street, then west on S. 5th Street to Pecan Street, then south on Pecan Street to S. 7th Street,
then west to Butternut Street for the southwest corner, then north on Butternut Street to S. 1st Street, then northeasterly along
the connecting roadway to N. 1st Street at Hickory Street, then north on Hickory Street to N. 7th Street, then west to Orange
Street, then north to the beginning point, the intersection of Orange Street and N. 8th Street.
The district to include all property within the above described streets and the full right-of-way of the boundary streets. This
prohibition includes, but is not limited to the following specific properties within the district: Everman Park, Minter Park,
T&P Freight Warehouse, the R.E.A. Building, T&P Depot, City Hall, Civic Center, and the Taylor County Courthouse.
(d) Said boundary as herein described shall continue in effect for the purpose of this section without regard to the expiration of the TIF
district or any changes to its stated boundary for tax collection purposes.
(e) Exceptions.
(1) Wheelchairs and other such devices to assist handicapped or physically impaired persons are excluded from the
provisions of this section.
(2) Registered participants in an approved parade, festival, celebration or similar event are excluded from the provisions of
this section to the extent of their approved participation.
(3) Uniformed public safety representatives are excluded from the provisions of this section while in the course of their
regular duties.
(4) Persons using, riding or operating a scooter or bicycle as authorized by chapter 23, scooter and bicycle sharing.
(Ord. No. 24-2000, pt. 1(Exh. A), 6-8-00; Ord. No. 20-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 4-11-19)
Sec. 18-11. Use of golf carts on public streets.
(a) Annually, from November 1 until December 31, parcel delivery services, including but not limited to United Parcel Service of
America, Inc. and FedEx Corp., may operate a golf cart on a portion of a public street within the City of Abilene that is:

(1) Within two miles of a golf course;
(2) Has a speed limit of not more than 35 miles per hour;
(3) Provides for no more than two lanes of vehicular traffic per direction; and
(4) Is not designated as part of the state or federal highway system.
(b) A golf cart operated pursuant to this ordinance must have headlamps, tail lamps, reflectors, a parking brake, and mirrors. Any

Secs. 18-12–18-20. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. ENFORCEMENT, OBEDIENCE
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 18-21. Duty of police officers.
It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, to enforce all street
traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city.
(Code 1965, § 17-2)
Sec. 18-22. Authority of police to direct traffic.
Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand
or signal in conformance with traffic laws, provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard
pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the
traffic laws.
(Code 1965, § 17-3)
Sec. 18-23. Authority of fire department to direct traffic.
Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate
vicinity.
(Code 1965, § 17-4)
Sec. 18-24. Temporary; experimental regulations.
The chief of police by and with the approval of the director of traffic and transportation is empowered to invoke regulations necessary to
make effective provisions of the traffic ordinances of this city and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or
special conditions. The director of traffic and transportation, by and with the approval of the city manager, is empowered to make
experimental regulations. No such temporary or experimental regulations shall remain in effect more than ninety (90) days.
(Code 1965, § 17-5)
Secs. 18-25–18-31. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU*
Sec. 18-32. Created.
There shall be a traffic violations bureau, the head of which shall be the municipal court clerk. The judge who hears traffic cases shall
designate the specified offenses under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city and the state traffic laws in respect to which
payments of fines may be accepted by the traffic violations bureau in satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the
amount of such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided such fines are within the limits declared by law or ordinances,
and shall further specify what number of such offenses shall require appearance before the judge.
(Code 1965, § 17-122)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 125/648
Sec. 18-33. Payment of fine.
The payment of a fine to the bureau shall be deemed an acknowledgement of conviction of the alleged offense, and the bureau, upon
accepting the prescribed fine, shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging payment thereof.
(Code 1965, § 17-123)
Sec. 18-34. Duties.
The following duties are imposed upon the traffic violations bureau:
(a) It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts and represent in court such violators as are permitted and desire to plead
guilty, waive court appearance, and give power of attorney.
(b) It shall receive and issue receipts for cash escrow deposits from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter
the time of their appearance on the court docket, and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present.
(c) It shall keep an easily accessible record of all violations of which each person has been guilty during the preceding
twelve (12) months, whether such guilt was established in court or in the traffic violations bureau.
(Code 1965, § 17-124)
Sec. 18-35. Records.
The traffic violations bureau shall keep record and submit summarized monthly reports to the city judge of all notices issued and arrests
made for violations of the traffic laws and ordinances in the city and of all the fines collected by the traffic violations bureau or court, and
of the final disposition or present status of every case of violation of the provisions of such laws and ordinances. Such records shall be so
maintained as to show all types of violations and total of each. Such records shall be public records.
(Code 1965, § 17-125)
Sec. 18-36. Additional duties of traffic violations bureau.
The traffic violations bureau shall follow such procedure as may be prescribed by this chapter and the traffic ordinances or as may be
required by any laws of this state.
(Code 1965, § 17-126)
Sec. 18-37. Reserved.
Editor's note: Part 2 of Ordinance 5-1994, adopted Feb. 24, 1994, repealed § 18-37 in its entirety. Formerly, § 18-37 pertained to minimum fines for parking
violations and doubling of fines upon becoming delinquent and derived from subsection (1) of Pt. 1 of Ordinance 133-1983, adopted Dec. 1, 1983.
Secs. 18-38–18-43. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. PENALTIES, PROCEDURES UPON ARREST
Sec. 18-44. Forms and records of traffic citations and arrests.
The municipal court clerk shall provide books to include traffic citation forms for notifying alleged violators to appear and answer to
charges of violating traffic laws and ordinances in the corporation court of the city. Such books shall include serially numbered sets of
citations in quadruplicate in the form prescribed and approved jointly by the judge of the municipal court and the municipal court clerk.
The municipal court clerk shall be responsible for the issuance of such books to individual members of the police department. The
municipal court clerk shall require a written receipt for every book so issued and shall maintain a record of every such book and each set
of citations contained therein.
(Code 1965, § 17-127; Ord. No. 5-1994, pt. 3, 2-24-94)
Sec. 18-45. Procedure of police officers.
Except when authorized or directed under state law to immediately take a person before a magistrate for the violation of any traffic laws,
a police officer who halts a person for such violation other than for the purpose of giving him a warning and does not take such person
into custody under arrest, shall take the name, address and the operator's license number of such person, the registered number of the
motor vehicle involved, and such other pertinent information as may be necessary, and shall issue to him in writing on a form as provided
for in section 18-44, a traffic citation containing a notice to answer to the charge against him in the municipal court at a time at least ten
(10) days after such alleged violation to be specified in such citation. The officer, upon receiving a written promise of the alleged violator
to answer as specified in the citation, shall release such person from custody.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 126/648
(Code 1965, § 17-128)
Sec. 18-46. Disposition and records of traffic citations, warrant and complaints.
Every police officer upon issuing a traffic citation to an alleged violator of any provision of the motor vehicle laws of this state or of any
traffic ordinance shall deposit the original and both duplicate copies of the citation with his immediate superior officer, who shall cause
them to be delivered to the municipal court. Upon the filing of such original citation in the municipal court such citation may be disposed
of only by trial in such court or by other official action by a judge of such court, including forfeiture of bail, cash escrow deposit, or by
payment of a fine to the traffic violations bureau. The judge of the municipal court shall require the return to him of each traffic citation
and all copies thereof, which has been spoiled or upon which any entry has been made and has not been issued to an alleged violator. The
chief of police shall establish a procedure not in conflict with this article for the voiding of traffic citations that are spoiled or improperly
or erroneously drawn. It shall be unlawful and official misconduct for any member of the police department or other officer or public
employee to dispose of, alter or deface a traffic citation or any copy thereof, or the record of the issuance or disposition of any traffic
citation, complaint or warrant, in a manner other than as required in this section.
(Code 1965, § 17-129)
Sec. 18-47. Illegal cancellation of traffic citations.
It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation in any manner other than as provided by this
chapter.
(Code 1965, § 17-130)
Sec. 18-48. Audit of records and reports.
Every record of traffic citations, complaints thereon, and warrants issued therefor required in this article shall be audited at least quarterly
by the director of finance who shall submit a report of such audit together with a summary thereof to the mayor and city council. Such
reports shall be public records. For the purpose of this section, the director of finance or his duly authorized representatives shall have
access at all times to all necessary records, files and papers of the municipal court, the traffic violations bureau, and the police
department.
(Code 1965, § 17-131)
Sec. 18-49. When copy of citation shall be deemed a lawful complaint.
In the event the form of citation provided under section 18-44 includes information and is sworn to as required under the general laws of
this state in respect to a complaint charging commission of the offense alleged in the citation to have been committed, then such citation
when filed with a court having jurisdiction shall be deemed to be a lawful complaint for the purpose of prosecution under this chapter.
(Code 1965, § 17-132)
Sec. 18-50. Citation on illegally parked vehicle.
Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter or
ordinance or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed
on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation requiring the driver to answer to
the charge against him at a time specified in the citation to be not less than twenty-four (24) hours nor more than ten (10) days from the
date of issuance of such citation.
(Code 1965, § 17-134)
Secs. 18-51, 18-52. Reserved.
Editor's note: Part 2 of Ordinance 5-1994, adopted Feb. 24, 1994, repealed §§ 18-51 and 18-52. Formerly, § 18-51 pertained to presumption in reference to illegal
parking and derived from § 17-135 of the 1965 Code; § 18-52 pertained to failure to comply with parking citation, warrants of arrest and impounding of vehicles and
derived from § 17-136 of the 1965 Code and subsection (2) of Pt. 1 of Ordinance 133-1983, adopted Dec. 1, 1983.
Sec. 18-53. Disposition of traffic fines and forfeitures.
All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail or cash escrow deposit of any person charged with a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into the city treasury and deposited in the general fund.
(Code 1965, § 17-137)
Sec. 18-54. Official misconduct.

Failure, refusal or neglect on the part of any judicial or other officer or employee receiving or having custody of any such fine or
forfeiture, either before or after a deposit in the general fund, to comply with the foregoing provisions of this article shall constitute
