ARTICLE III. COLLECTION
Sec. 27-21. Commercial collection.
(a) Roll-off service will be provided for large volume municipal solid waste customers.
(b) Roll-off service will be provided either through stationary compactors or open top metal containers as determined by the manager.
(c) Municipal solid waste containing putrescible waste shall be collected at least once a week pursuant to state law, or more frequently
for public health concerns if designated by the administrator.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Sec. 27-22. Residential collection.
Residential collection shall be provided through curbside roll-out service, alley service, or manual collection as determined by the
manager.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Sec. 27-23. Bulky solid waste requirements.
The following requirements must be met for bulky waste collection. The solid waste services division may decline to accept items
containing other municipal solid waste, contraband, hazardous wastes or regulated items that cannot be disposed of in the landfill.
Occupants should check the solid waste service division's web site or call the solid waste services division for collection schedules.
(1) Only bulky waste generated by the occupant of the place of collection is eligible for collection.
(2) Bulky waste must be placed where designated by the administrator.
(3) Any claim of ownership to the bulky waste is relinquished when the waste is collected by the solid waste services
division.
(4) Small items lying loose on the ground shall be bagged, tied, and placed into the collection container by the occupant for
proper collection.
(5) Bulky waste shall not be commingled with yard waste or other municipal solid wastes.
(6) Doors on refrigerators and other bulky waste with affixed doors or panels shall be removed or disabled to prevent
closure before placement for collection.
(7) Uncontained bulky waste shall be limited to a total volume of less than four (4) by three (3) by eight (8) feet. It is the
responsibility of the occupant to notify the solid waste services division of excessive amounts or undue accumulations of
waste and arrange for collection. Such service shall be subject to the scheduling and availability of solid waste services
division's personnel and equipment. Rates are listed in the “schedule of rates and charges” for the solid waste services
division.
(8) Tree limbs shall be cut to a length of four (4) feet or less.
(9) Any tree trunks, tree stumps or root balls shall be free of dirt, less than four (4) feet in length, and weigh less than fifty
(50) pounds.
(10) Fencing and fence posts shall be cut into four (4) foot lengths, void of protruding nails, and neatly stacked. Concrete
bases are not handled by the solid waste services division and shall be removed by occupant.
(11) Bulky waste shall be placed so as to allow ten (10) feet of clearance from collection containers, utility meters and other
fixed obstacles.
(12) For alley collection, bulky waste must be placed in the alley in the rear of the residence where the waste was generated
so as not to block traffic in the alley.
(13) For alley collection, bulky waste shall be placed at the approved collection location no sooner than ten (10) days before
the published schedule of collection for the given area.
(14) For curb collection, bulky waste must be placed behind the curb in front of the property where the waste was generated
so as not to block any sidewalk.
(15) For curb collection, bulky waste shall be placed at the approved collection location no sooner than forty-eight (48)
hours before the published monthly schedule of collection for the given area.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 275/648
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Secs. 27-24, 27-25. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. PROHIBITIONS
Sec. 27-26. Prohibited acts.
The following items, condition, or actions are hereby declared to be prohibited under this chapter and are therefore unlawful. Waste
prohibited for collection shall be disposed of directly, promptly and properly in an approved and legal location by the occupant of the
premises where such material is accumulated. Removal of bulky/uncontained items prohibited from placement in collection containers
may be provided at rates listed in the “schedule of rates and charges” for the solid waste services division. This list shall not be deemed or
construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive:
(1) No person other than a duly authorized employee of the city or law enforcement official acting within the official scope
of duties shall collect or remove any solid waste or recyclable material from a solid waste collection container used for
municipal solid waste or recycling collection.
(2) No person other than a duly authorized employee or agent of the city shall empty city-owned solid waste or recycling
collection containers.
(3) The following items shall NOT be placed in any collection container:
a. Tires, oil, oil filters, lead acid batteries, commercial pesticides for residential use, liquid mercury as contained in
thermometers and mercury switches and any waste that is not permitted to be landfilled by the US Environmental
Protection Agency or the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. These regulated items shall be disposed of at the
household hazardous waste unit in the environmental recycling center or as allowed by related programs.
b. Hazardous waste, special waste and industrial waste.
c. Medical waste not properly treated or contained.
d. Needles/sharps improperly contained that constitute a sticking hazard.
(4) The following items shall NOT be placed in residential collection containers:
a. Dead animals.
b. Major construction and demolition waste.
c. Any solid waste items likely to damage city collection equipment including but not limited to rocks, engine blocks,
steel, and lead pipes.
d. Unbagged leaves, grass clippings, shrubbery trimmings, and tree prunings.
e. Large tree stumps with root balls.
f. Tree trunks greater than six (6) inches in diameter and eighteen (18) inches in length or of a bulk weight of more
than fifty (50) pounds.
g. Any items defined as bulky waste in section 27-5.
(5) No person shall place, or permit another to place, any municipal solid waste in any solid waste collection container
unless the solid waste is from the premises served by the collection container.
(6) No person shall off-load municipal solid waste at an unauthorized location or at a facility not authorized to accept such
waste.
(7) No person shall park in such a manner that would interfere with the collection of municipal solid waste from any
collection container serviced by the solid waste services division. Blocked collection containers will not be emptied.
(8) On the day of normally scheduled municipal solid waste collection, the parking of a vehicle or trailer perpendicular or
diagonal to a curb within a cul-de-sac with roll-out collection service, shall be considered an obstruction to the removal of
solid waste from a solid waste collection container, and the collection container will not be emptied.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Sec. 27-27. Exceptions.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 276/648
This section shall not prohibit any occupant from removing solid waste from the premises under their control to an approved landfill or
recycling site.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Secs. 27-28–27-30. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 27-31. Declared a nuisance.
Except where remedy has been specifically designated herein, violations of this chapter shall constitute a violation of chapter 19,
“nuisances and illegal dumping” and enforcement shall proceed under that chapter.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Sec. 27-32. Additional remedies.
(a) The manager may authorize discontinuance of service where any user repeatedly violates any of the provisions of this chapter.
(b) For curb collection, if a collection container is not removed from the curb by 8:00 a.m. the day after the collection day, the
following procedure will take place.
(1) A notice describing the violation will be affixed to the collection container or left with the occupant.
(2) After the third notice within ninety (90) days, the container may be removed by the city and returned after payment of a
service fee as set in the “schedule of rates and charges” for the solid waste services division.
(Ord. No. 10-2007, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-22-07)
Secs. 27-33–27-50. Reserved.
Chapter 28
SOLICITATIONS*
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL*
Sec. 28-1. Purpose of chapter.
The purpose of this chapter is to protect against criminal activity, including fraud and burglary, protect the privacy of the citizens of the
city, and to otherwise preserve the public health, safety, and welfare. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt.
1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-2. City license officer.
For the purposes of this chapter, the city secretary shall act as the city license officer and as such shall administer the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-3. Definitions.
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section:
Business day. Any calendar day except Saturday, Sunday or any city holiday.
City manager. The city manager of the City of Abilene or designee.
Official. City peace officers, city secretary, or city manager or designee who ministers, implements, and enforces the provisions of this
chapter.
Solicitation or solicit. The action of any solicitor, peddler, hawker, itinerant merchant or transient vendor of merchandise to go in and
upon a private residence in the city, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such residence, for the
purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of services, goods, wares and merchandise, or for the purpose of disposing of or peddling or
hawking such services, goods, wares and merchandise, or to request contribution of funds or anything of value.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 277/648
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-4. Hours of solicitation at private residences.
Solicitation shall be unlawful at private residences between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. unless otherwise posted by the private
property owner or by someone with apparent authority to act for the owner. This provision does not apply where the person is on the
property by express, prior invitation of the owner of the property or a person residing on the premises. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A),
1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-5. Entry upon premises unlawful.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit at any time upon any private property in the city where the owner, occupant, or person
legally in charge of the premises has posted at the entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, the
words “no solicitation,” or words of similar import.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit at any entrance to a residence other than the front door.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Secs. 28-6–28-10. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. PERMIT
Sec. 28-11. Permit requirements and exemptions.
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit within the city without first obtaining a permit issued by the city license officer, unless
otherwise exempted by state or federal law. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-12. Exhibition of permit required.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to, while soliciting, fail to conspicuously display on or about their person the permit issued by
the city.
(b) “Conspicuously displayed” shall mean displayed to the front and visible to whomever the permit holder is conversing at all times
they are engaged in a permitted activity.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-13. Permits for minor solicitors.
(a) No person under the age of 18 shall be permitted to engage in soliciting except as provided in this section.
(b) A permit shall be obtained by a sponsoring person, company, or organization for the conduct of any solicitation activities involving
in whole or in part a sales force of one or more persons under the age of eighteen years of age.
(c) The sponsor shall be responsible for supervising and controlling all persons soliciting under the sponsor's permit.
(d) The sponsor shall provide to each individual in its sales force a badge or other easily readable form of identification that identifies
the name of the sponsor and the name of the individual. The sponsor shall require all individuals in their sales force to wear the
identification so that it is clearly visible at all times while soliciting.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-14. Application.
Applicants for permits under this chapter must file with the city license officer an application in writing on a form obtained from the
license officer and provide the following:
(1) A valid state issued driver's license or state issued photo identification.
(2) The number of the limited sales tax permit issued to the business by the state comptroller's office, if applicable.
(3) A brief description of the activity or business to be conducted.
(4) The appropriate fee.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-15. Required fee.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 278/648
The fees and charges for permits furnished by the city shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
license officer. No application for a permit will be processed until the required fees are tendered to the city license officer. Permit fees are
nonrefundable and shall not be prorated. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-16. Exceptions to fee.
The payment of the permit fee shall not be held to be applicable to the following organizations, however, all solicitors and peddlers are
required to comply with all other applicable provisions of this chapter unless otherwise exempted:
(a) Any local church or other religious group, or to ministers or agents thereof soliciting funds for the support of such
religious group;
(b) Any established society, association or corporation that is organized and operated exclusively for educational,
philanthropic, benevolent, fraternal or charitable purposes, not operated for pecuniary profit, where no part of the net earnings
inures to the benefit of any person, private shareholder, or individual, where the solicitation of such organization is:
(1) Conducted among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without
remuneration for such solicitation; or
(2) In the form of collections or contributions at the regular exercises or services of any society, lodge, benevolent
order or fraternity or similar organization, or any branch thereof.
(c) Vendors of farm produce, poultry, stock or agricultural products in their natural state if raised on land owned or leased
by the vendor, or such products may be sold by any member of the owner's or lessee's household.
(d) Sales of goods, wares, and merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds of which are to be used and applied
to some charitable, religious or philanthropic purposes.
(e) Sales of goods, wares, and merchandise by any bonafide charitable, religious or philanthropic organization.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-17. Issuance.
Upon completion and presentation of the application, the city license officer shall issue a permit to the applicant within 5 business days
unless grounds for denial exist under section 28-21. (Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-18. Contents.
(a) Each permit issued under this article shall show the name of the permitted individual, business address, a description of the type of
solicitation, the date of issuance, and the expiration date of such permit.
(b) The permit shall be numbered and printed in black; except, that the following shall be printed prominently thereon in red: “The
issuance of this license is not an endorsement by the City of Abilene, or any of its officers or employees, and expires ________.”
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-19. Expiration.
All permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire 30 days from the date of issuance.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-20. Transfer.
No permit issued under the provision of this article shall be transferred or assigned.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Sec. 28-21. Denial.
An application for permit may be denied to a person under this article for the following reasons.
(1) Because of a person's conviction of a felony or misdemeanor if the crime directly relates to fraudulent or deceitful
conduct of a solicitor or solicitor's business or results from an assault against person.
(2) An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application.
(3) The applicant is a registered sex offender.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 279/648
(4) The applicant has had a permit revoked for any reason within the past three years.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-22. Revocation.
(a) Permits issued under the provision of this article may be revoked for any of the following causes by any official of the city:
(1) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit.
(2) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business.
(3) Any violation of this chapter.
(4) Conviction of a misdemeanor or any felony if the crime directly relates to the conduct of the business.
(5) Conducting the business of solicitation in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace
or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, and general welfare of the public.
(b) Notice of revocation of a permit shall be given verbally or in writing, and specify the grounds of the revocation.
(c) When the solicitor receives notice that their permit has been revoked, they shall immediately surrender their permit to the revoking
official.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-28-19)
Sec. 28-23. Appeals.
(a) An appeal from any act of denial or revocation of any permit shall be filed with the city manager within five (5) business days from
the date of denial or revocation.
(b) Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city manager a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal.
(c) The city manager shall issue a decision on the denial or revocation in writing within 5 business days of receipt of the appeal.
(d) The revocation or denial is not stayed pending the city manager's decision.
(e) The decision and order of the city manager on such appeal shall be final and conclusive.
(Ord. No. 1-2012, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 1-12-12)
Secs. 28-24–28-30. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. PENALTY*
Sec. 28--31. Penalty.
Any person who engages in any activity specifically prohibited in this chapter, may be subject to prosecution for a class C misdemeanor
and a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. No. 63-2013, pt. 2(Exh. A), 11-21-13; Ord. No. 12-2019, pt. 1(Exh. A), 2-
28-19)
Chapter 29
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS*
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 29-1. Authority to change lines, grades of streets.
The city, when putting down a permanent street pavement either by original construction or reconstruction, may change or alter the lines
and grades of such street, when in the opinion of the city engineer such change is necessary for the proper pavement or drainage of such
street, without liability on the part of the city by reason of such change.
(Code 1965, § 26-1)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 280/648
Sec. 29-2. Street, sidewalk, etc., contractors–Bond required.
No person shall engage in the business of construction, alteration, maintenance, repair and paving of streets, alleys and other public ways
and the construction or repair of sidewalks, curbs, gutters, bridges or culverts in the city until he has first filed with the building official a
surety bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), approved by the city council, payable to the city and conditioned on the
faithful performance of the rules and regulations of this Code and any other ordinances of the city and the specifications and plans of the
city engineer governing such work, and the surety on such bond shall be a company authorized to transact business in the state.
(Code 1965, § 26-2)
Sec. 29-3. Same–Insurance required.
Before any contractor shall engage in the work of constructing, altering, maintaining, repairing and paving of streets, alleys and other
public ways and constructing or repairing sidewalks, curbs, gutters, bridges or culverts in the city he shall file with the city engineer, and
thereafter keep in full force and effect, a policy of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in
the state, which policy shall be approved by the city council and shall be performed in the county, insuring the public against any loss or
damage that may result to any person or property caused by the negligent or willful acts of such contractor or his agents or employees in
such construction or growing out of such construction. The amount of recovery in such policy of insurance shall conform to the
requirements of the state torts claim act. All policies of insurance shall contain a provision for continuing liability thereon up to the full
amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon. It shall be the duty of such contractor and the insurer to give notice to the city, by
filing a written notice with the city engineer, of the expiration of such policy of insurance at least ten (10) days before the expiration
thereof.
(Code 1965, § 26-3)
Sec. 29-4. Goods, wares and merchandise on sidewalks.
No person shall place or cause to be placed any box, barrel, wood, hardware, goods, wares and merchandise or any substance or thing and
permit the same to remain on any sidewalk or store or cause to be stored or placed any box, barrel, wood, hardware, goods, wares,
merchandise or any other substance on any sidewalk; provided, that the adjacent property owner may occupy not more than one-half the
width of any sidewalk in front of his place of business for a reasonable length of time in receiving and forwarding goods, wares and
merchandise.
(Code 1965, § 26-5)
Sec. 29-5. Reserved.
Editor's note–Former section 29-5, which pertained to peddling in roadways, was deleted in its entirety by Ordinance 63-2013, pt. 1, adopted on November 21,
2013. Prior to its deletion, this section derived from the 1965 Code, § 26-6. Similar provisions can be found in chapter 28, article III.
Sec. 29-6. Defacing, marking, painting, etc., sidewalks, curbs, pavement, etc.
No person shall carve, mark, stain or paint with any substance any sign or advertisement on any sidewalk, pavement, gutter or curb within
the city or otherwise willfully deface or discolor the same. The word “deface” as used in this section shall apply to carving, marking or
breaking any such sidewalk, pavement, gutter or curb, or staining the same with any substance that will produce a discoloration of the
same.
This section shall not apply to the painting or marking of house numbers or street addresses upon curbs on driveway approaches so long
as the colors red or yellow are not used or the width of the area painted for each house number or street address does not exceed twentyfour
(24) inches.
(Code 1965, § 26-7; Ord. No. 29-1982, pt. 1, 3-25-82)
Sec. 29-7. Notice of defects or obstructions required prior to making claim for injuries sustained therefrom.
Any person who shall have actual knowledge of any obstruction or defect in the streets, curbs or sidewalks for a sufficient length of time
to have notified the city of such, and for the city to have removed such obstruction or repaired such defect after such notice, and who fails
to notify or cause to be notified, the city secretary in writing, of such defect or obstruction for a sufficient length of time for the city to
have removed the obstruction or repaired the defect, before any injury complained of, shall have no cause of action against the city on
account of personal injuries received by him because of such defect or obstruction. This section shall apply to actions by representatives
of beneficiaries of decedents, for injuries resulting in death of the injured person, who shall have no greater rights to sue the city than
such decedent would have had, had he lived. The provisions of this section shall not apply to idiots, lunatics, blind persons, children or
other persons who are incapable of knowing of such obstruction or defect.
(Code 1965, § 26-9)
Sec. 29-8. Placement of utility poles to conform to established lines.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 281/648
All posts or poles installed for the purpose of transmission or distribution of electric energy or communication in any street, alley,
sidewalk or public highway in the city shall be placed so as to conform to the lines established by the city engineer.
(Code 1965, § 26-36)
Sec. 29-9. Barricades and warning devices for post holes.
Any person digging or causing to be dug post holes under this article in any street, alley, sidewalk or public highway shall keep the same
well guarded with approved warning devices placed at such holes, or shall keep such holes securely covered.
(Code 1965, § 26-37)
Secs. 29-10–29-20. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. OBSTRUCTIONS*
Sec. 29-21. Exceptions.
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to apply to or regulate signs or billboards.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 29-22. Enumeration.
The following are declared to be obstructions or traffic hazards subject to the regulations of this section:
(a) Any awning or other protrusion which hangs over or protrudes over any sidewalk or parkway in the city at a height of
less than eight (8) feet above the sidewalk or ground level.
(b) Any awning or other protrusion attached to the wall of any building or structure which projects over any sidewalk or
public space farther than:
(1) Four (4) feet behind the curb where the height of such awning or protrusion is less than ten (10) feet, or
(2) Two (2) feet behind the curb where the height of such awning or protrusion is ten (10) feet or more.
(c) Any bush, tree or other vegetation within the parkway which exceeds a height of two and one-half (2 1/2) feet above the
gutter elevation of the adjacent street or which overhangs a sidewalk, except single trunk trees which are pruned to eliminate
all leaves and branches as follows:
(1) Below seven (7) feet in height above the ground beneath the tree;
(2) Below eight (8) feet in height above a sidewalk beneath the tree; or
(3) Which would tend to obstruct the view of a traffic-control device.
(d) Any bush, tree or other vegetation which hangs over any street or alley which is not pruned as follows:
(1) To eliminate all leaves and branches below a height of thirteen and one-half (13 1/2) feet above the street or alley;
or
(2) To eliminate all leaves or branches which would tend to obstruct the view of a traffic-control device.
(Code 1965, § 26-4; Ord. No. 109-1984, pt. 1, 11-1-84)
Sec. 29-23. Notice to remove.
The director of traffic and transportation, or such other person as may be designated by the city manager, when it shall come to his
knowledge that any of the above obstructions, nuisances or traffic hazards exist shall notify the responsible person that the same is in
violation of this section and request that the same be either remedied or eliminated as deemed necessary by the notifying official. The
person so notified shall have ten (10) days in which to comply with such notice.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 29-24. Action by city upon failure to remove.
In the event that any person, for any reason, fails to comply with a notice issued under the provisions of this article within the prescribed
period, the city shall take the necessary steps to abate the condition described in such notice. Expenses incident to such action by the city,
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 282/648
and a penalty charge as established by the city council, shall be assessed against the owners of all outstanding interests in such lot or
parcel. An itemized bill of such costs shall be mailed by the city accountant to each such owner if his address is known.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 29-25. Lien imposed, enforcement.
If the bill provided for in section 29-24 remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after the date of the mailing of such bill, the city
accountant shall file a statement of such bill and the reasons therefor with the county clerk. From the date of such filing, the city shall
have a lien on the lot or parcel upon which such expenses are incurred second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. The
amount of such debt shall accumulate interest at the rate of ten (10) per cent per annum from the date on which payment was due. For any
such debt and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure had in the name of the city. In such suits, the aforementioned
statement, or certified copy thereof, shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the debt and all interest thereon.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 29-26. Violation deemed misdemeanor.
It shall be the duty of any person owning, leasing or occupying any lot or parcel of land in the city fronting upon a sidewalk, street or
alley to remove and prohibit any of the nuisances, obstructions or traffic hazards set out in this article, and failure to remedy, eliminate or
modify the same in accordance with the instructions of the notifying official shall be a violation of the provisions of this article and shall
be punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 29-27. Emergency situation.
If the director of traffic and transportation shall determine that any of the above obstructions, nuisances, or traffic hazards constitute an
emergency situation or immediate hazard, then the director may cause the immediate removal of said obstruction, nuisance, or traffic
hazard.
(Ord. No. 109-1984, pt. 1, 11-1-84)
Secs. 29-28–29-37. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. SIDEWALK, DRIVEWAY, CURB AND GUTTER CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 29-38. Duty of abutting property owner to repair and maintain sidewalks, sidewalk amenities, landscaping, driveways and
curbs.
(a) It shall be the duty of all persons owning real property within the city to keep any sidewalk, sidewalk amenities, landscaping,
driveway or curb abutting their property in good repair. Whenever a sidewalk, sidewalk amenity, landscaping, driveway or curb shall
become defective or dangerous, such owner shall reconstruct or repair the same at his expense.
(b) Each owner of real property shall keep the abutting sidewalks and sidewalk amenities free from snow, ice and other hazardous
substance.
(c) The owner of property abutting on any public street containing a sidewalk, sidewalk amenity, landscaping, driveway or curb that
has become defective and has resulted in causing damage or injury as a result of such defective or dangerous condition shall be solely
liable in damages for any loss or damage sustained as a result of such defective condition. The city shall not be held as assuming any such
liability by reason of inspection or reinspection authorized herein or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any construction made or
not made in accordance with standards or specifications of this chapter or other applicable provisions of this Code.
(Code 1965, § 26-10; Ord. No. 31-2008, pt. 1(Exh. A), 6-26-08)
Sec. 29-39. Notice to repair.
Notice to repair any defective or dangerous sidewalk may be given to the abutting property owner by the city engineer by personal service
or by mail to such owner's last known address. Upon the service of such notice, the owner shall comply with its terms within thirty (30)
days.
(Code 1965, § 26-10)
Sec. 29-40. Repair of sidewalks, curbs or driveway cutaways by city.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 283/648
Should any person owning any property abutting on or adjacent to any street fail or refuse to repair any curb, driveway or sidewalk or
portions thereof in the manner required in this article, the city may proceed to repair or cause to be repaired such sidewalks, curb or
driveway cutaway, and the cost of repairing the same shall be charged against the owners of such adjacent or abutting property.
(Code 1965, § 26-11)
Sec. 29-41. City's cost declared lien.
The city's cost of work performed by it under the provisions of this article, together with legal interest and cost of collection, shall
constitute a personal claim against the abutting property owner and shall be secured by a lien on such property superior to all other liens,
claims or titles, except lawful taxes. Such lien may be enforced against such owner by suit in any court having competent jurisdiction.
(Code 1965, § 26-11)
Sec. 29-42. Applicability of article in connection with new construction.
This article, in addition to other situations set out in this article, shall apply to and govern the construction or reconstruction of sidewalks,
driveways, recess parking or curb and gutter in connection with the erection of buildings in the city.
(Code 1965, § 26-12)
Sec. 29-43. Notification of utilities prior to beginning construction work.
It shall be the duty of any owner, agent or contractor, before the construction, reconstruction or repair of any sidewalk, driveway, recess
parking area or curb and gutter along and abutting on the property of such owner, or over which such agent has control, or in front of
which such contractor intends to make such improvements, to notify in writing the water and sewer superintendent of the city and the
light and gas companies of such intentions within a reasonable time before such work shall begin, in order that all water, gas and sewer
pipes and connections may be properly placed before construction is begun.
(Code 1965, § 26-16)
Sec. 29-44. Compliance with lines, grades, specifications, etc.; supervision.
All sidewalks constructed, reconstructed or repaired in the city shall be under the supervision of the city engineer and shall conform to
lines, grades and specifications furnished by the city engineer. Persons repairing or causing to be repaired such sidewalks shall comply
with all regulatory ordinances of the city governing such matters.
(Code 1965, § 26-17)
Sec. 29-45. Type material to be used for construction, etc.
Sidewalks, driveways, recess parking areas and curbs and gutters shall be constructed of concrete or asphalt. All such work shall be
inspected by the city engineer and approved by him before such work is accepted by the city.
(Code 1965, § 26-18)
Sec. 29-46. Property between sidewalk and curb to conform to established grade.
The owner of any lot or real estate of any kind within the city in front of or along which a sidewalk, driveway, recess parking area or curb
and gutter is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired shall conform his property to the sidewalk grade abutting upon such property
which lies between such property line and the proper curbline in the street by cutting down or filling up the same, as may be necessary to
conform to such grade, and such owner shall pay all costs and expenses of such work.
(Code 1965, § 26-19)
Sec. 29-47. Gutters to be kept open; removal of debris, etc., upon completion of work.
Any person engaging in work under this article shall, during the time such work is being done, keep all gutters open so as not to interfere
with the drainage thereof, and shall upon the completion of such work remove all building material or other accumulation of debris on the
premises caused by such work.
(Code 1965, § 26-20)
Sec. 29-48. Installation of sidewalks required.
Installation of sidewalks shall be required relative to any new construction or substantial improvement on any lot or tract of land in
accordance with the sidewalk master plan as adopted by the city council. A final inspection or certificate of occupancy shall be withheld
until such sidewalk has been installed in conformance with city standards and policies.

(Ord. No. 43-1987, pt. 1, 7-9-87)
Secs. 29-49–29-54. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 29-55. Required.
No person shall open or take up any sidewalk, driveway, recess parking area or curbing without a written permit having first been
obtained by the owner, agent or contractor from the city engineer.
(Code 1965, § 26-13)
Sec. 29-56. Exception.
No permit shall be required under the provisions of this division for street paving, nor for curb and gutter work when such curb and gutter
is a part of the street paving project.
(Code 1965, § 26-13)
Sec. 29-57. Application.
Application for the permit required by the provisions of this division shall be made to the city engineer on such forms and containing such
information as he shall prescribe.
(Code 1965, § 26-14)
Sec. 29-58. Fees.
The fees and charges for services furnished by the city, shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
secretary.
(Code 1965, § 26-15; Ord. No. 65-1986, pt. 1, 8-28-86)
Sec. 29-59. Issuance.
Permits required by the provisions of this division shall be issued on such terms and conditions as the city engineer may prescribe.
(Code 1965, § 26-14)
Secs. 29-60–29-70. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. UNDERGROUND ENCROACHMENTS
Sec. 29-71. Franchise–Required.
No person shall use or appropriate to his own use any area under any sidewalk, parkway or public street in the city without first having
obtained a franchise therefor and paying the fees provided in this article.
(Code 1965, § 26-21)
Sec. 29-72. Same–Application.
Any person desiring to use or appropriate to his own use for commercial or private purposes any area beneath any sidewalk, parkway or
public street shall first make application to the city council for a franchise for such use, which application shall state the nature of the use
to which such area is to be put, the location of the same, the legal description of the abutting property and a description by metes and
bounds of the public property sought to be employed, together with an accurate survey prepared by a licensed surveyor and a plat
showing the exact location of the area sought to be used with respect to existing buildings, lines, sidewalks, streets, utility lines and poles,
and all other structures pertinent to or which may be affected by the proposed excavation.
(Code 1965, § 26-22)
Sec. 29-73. Same–Fees.
For the privilege of a franchise under this article the grantee thereof shall pay to the city in advance an annual fee computed at the rate of
two cents ($0.02) per cubic foot of any public property so used. In addition the grantee shall pay in advance an annual fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for any sidewalk elevator or lift used in connection with the subsurface structure.
(Code 1965, § 26-23)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 285/648
Sec. 29-74. Same–Grant or denial; provisions and terms.
The city council may in its discretion deny a franchise under this article or may by ordinance grant such franchise with any modification
which may be deemed right and proper.
Such franchise ordinance shall provide that the grantee shall assume full and complete responsibility and liability for keeping the
premises in a safe condition up to the time of final completion of the construction project and approval and acceptance by the city
engineer. Such franchise shall further provide that the sub-area and the covering surface shall be kept in a safe condition throughout the
period of time covered by the franchise and that the grantee shall be liable and shall indemnify the city against liability to any person
injured or property damaged arising out of, or in any way related to the granting of such franchise.
(Code 1965, § 26-24)
Sec. 29-75. Approval of plans and specifications; filing of liability insurance policy.
After the granting of a franchise under this article no work thereunder shall be commenced and no building permit shall be issued until
the complete plans and specifications therefor have been presented to the city engineer for study. After the approval of such plans and
specifications by the city engineer, he shall so notify the applicant who shall, prior to beginning any excavation work, file in the office of
the city secretary a public liability insurance policy in any amount required by the franchise ordinance.
(Code 1965, § 26-25)
Sec. 29-76. Use of lift or elevator.
The plans and specifications of any elevator or lift used in connection with a franchise granted under this article, together with covers and
guards used in connection therewith, shall be subject to inspection and study by the city engineer and all reasonable changes ordered by
the city engineer shall be made. The operation of such lift or elevator together with all appurtenances shall be fully covered by liability
insurance throughout the period of the franchise.
(Code 1965, § 26-26)
Sec. 29-77. Defective or unsafe structures.
All property included within any franchise issued under the provisions of this article shall be subject to inspection by the agents and
employees of the city at all reasonable times, and when any such excavations or structures are found to be defective from an engineering
standpoint or structurally unsafe for any reason, such unsafe condition that be a public nuisance. When such defective structure is found
to exist, the city engineer shall give notice in writing to the franchise holder who shall immediately commence the reconstruction or
repair of such structure so as to render the same safe. The failure of the franchise holder to remedy the defects pointed out by the city
engineer within a reasonable time shall operate to automatically revoke the franchise issued under the terms of this article.
(Code 1965, § 26-27)
Sec. 29-78. Barriers, etc., to be erected during construction.
It shall be the duty of the franchise holder under this article, the owner of the abutting property and the contractor, their agents and
employees, to erect suitable fences and barriers as directed by the city engineer so as to adequately protect the public and all persons
lawfully using the streets, sidewalks and parkways against injuries to their person and damage to public and private property.
(Code 1965, § 26-28)
Secs. 29-79–29-89. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. STREET USE LICENSES
Sec. 29-90. Applicability and purpose of article.
The purpose of this article is to provide a method to license or permit the privilege of making use of public streets, alleys, sidewalks or
other public ways which would otherwise be unlawful, and nothing in this article shall be deemed to conflict with sections 110 to 117 of
the Charter of the city requiring franchises in order to use the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways by public utilities in
order to furnish a public service which the public has a right to demand.
This article shall not apply where other provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city govern the use of streets, alleys, sidewalks
and other public ways by specific occupations.
(Code 1965, § 26-29; Ord. No. 53-1986, pt. 1, 7-24-86; Ord. No. 18-1988, pt. 1, 4-21-88)
Sec. 29-91. Required.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 286/648
No person shall place any encroachment within any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public way or appropriate any portion thereof to
a private use without first obtaining a street, alley, sidewalk or public way use license from the city.
(Code 1965, § 26-30; Ord. No. 53-1986, pt. 1, 7-24-86; Ord. No. 18-1988, pt. 1, 4-21-88)
Sec. 29-92. Application.
All applications for a license to make a specific use of the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways shall be made to the
director of public works. Such application shall be made on a form provided by the director of public works for that purpose. The
applicant shall state the complete purpose for making the application and all facts the director of public works deems pertinent to the
granting of such license. All information furnished by the applicant shall be correctly stated; otherwise, any license issued thereunder may
be declared void by the city manager or city council.
(Code 1965, § 26-31; Ord. No. 33-2016, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 7-28-16)
Sec. 29-93. Approval.
(a) All street, alley, sidewalk or public way license agreements prepared by the director of public works shall be submitted to the city
manager if the duration of the license is for thirty (30) days or less, and to the city council for approval if the duration of the license is for
greater than thirty (30) days.
(b) In the event the city manager denies a license application, the applicant may appeal the decision to city council by filing a written
appeal with the city secretary within ten (10) business days after the denial of the license application is mailed to the applicant or
personally delivered, whichever occurs first. If no appeal is filed within ten (10) business days, the decision of the city manager becomes
final and unappealable. The written appeal should contain all information on which the city council can make a decision. The city council
shall hear the appeal within thirty (30) days after the appeal is filed with the city secretary.
(Code 1965, § 26-32; Ord. No. 33-2016, pt. 1 (Exh. A), 7-28-16)
Sec. 29-94. Contents; terms and conditions.
All street, alley, sidewalk or public way use license agreements shall state the specific nature of the use granted and the term thereof; shall
provide that the city will be held harmless and indemnified against bodily injury or property damage claims or suits arising out of or
connected with the issuance of such license; shall provide for revocation of such license upon thirty (30) days' notice, or sooner in case of
a violation of the agreement; and shall contain such other terms as may be appropriate.
(Code 1965, § 26-33)
Sec. 29-95. Application fee.
The fees and charges for services furnished by the city, shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
secretary.
(Ord. No. 65-1986, pt. 1, 8-28-86)
Secs. 29-96–29-105. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. STREET OR ALLEY EXCAVATIONS
Sec. 29-106. Definition.
A standard trench shall be interpreted as one which does not exceed thirty (30) inches in width and which does not extend more than
fifteen (15) inches beyond the center line of the utility main, and is not lower than the utility main. Permit holders will be required to pay
the extra cost, as estimated by the street superintendent, for repairs made by the city where the width and/or length and/or depth of a
trench exceeds that of the standard trench. The permit holder will be billed for extra width and/or length and/or depth immediately upon
completion of work by the city.
(Code 1965, § 26-50)
Sec. 29-107. Waiver of standards.
The standards established in this article may be waived by the director of public works of the city only if the street or alley is in a
relatively undeveloped are area and development is not anticipated which would necessitate improvement of the street or alley within two
(2) years.
(Code 1965, § 26-51)
Sec. 29-108. Permit required.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 287/648
Anyone desiring to make an excavation in any public right-of-way, particularly any street, alley or parkway within the city shall first
obtain a permit from the city building official.
(Code 1965, § 26-45)
Sec. 29-109. Application.
All applications for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a fee as below provided and, in all cases,
by a written description or a sketch showing the approximate location of the proposed excavation and the location of all underground
utilities in the immediate vicinity, which description or sketch shall have been verified by the city engineering department, the electric
utility company, the natural gas utility company and any other firms, parties or agencies whose approval may be reasonably required for a
particular permit by the city building official. The application shall reflect the name of the individual approving said description or
sketches, and the time and date of approval, at the foot thereof.
(Code 1965, § 26-45)
Sec. 29-110. Backfill, repair charges–Required.
The fees and charges for services furnished by the city, shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city
secretary.
(Code 1965, § 26-46; Ord. No. 65-1986, pt. 1, 8-28-86)
Sec. 29-111. Same–Exception.
All holders of franchises for the use of streets and alleys from the city shall be exempt from the backfill and repair charges, except for
charges for work done by the city for franchise holders.
(Code 1965, § 26-46)
Sec. 29-112. Manner of work.
Excavation shall be done in a manner which disturbs the minimum area of the right-of-way. Adequate measures will be taken to insure
minimum interference with use by the public of the right-of-way and minimum damage to adjacent areas. Only those methods and
techniques which have been approved by the director of public works of the city will be used.
(Code 1965, § 26-47)
Sec. 29-113. Backfilling.
Backfilling shall be done by one or more of the following methods:
(a) Backfill with clean, dry sand or gravel. This method is preferred in most cases; however, the permittee may choose other
methods.
(b) Compacted backfill with natural material. This method requires compaction of existing soil in layers not exceeding six
(6) inches deep and with adequate moisture to compact soil to a density equivalent to adjacent undisturbed soil.
(c) Backfill compaction may be achieved by jetting. This method requires the trench area to be flooded and the soil
completely saturated to insure total consolidation and elimination of voids. Normally, this method will require a minimum of
two (2) or three (3) saturation cycles to effect adequate consolidation.
(d) Combinations of the above methods.
(e) A substitute method which has been approved in writing for a peculiar situation. Written approval of a substitute method
shall apply to a specified job only and shall not be construed as establishing a new standard method.
Regardless of method, all excavations shall be backfilled level with adjacent areas and the base material and surfacing installed must be
of at least equivalent grade and thickness to that of the adjacent area.
(Code 1965, § 26-47)
Sec. 29-114. Cleanup.
All excess material shall be removed from the right-of-way after an excavation. The backfilled area shall be smoothly and uniformly
finished to match adjacent grades. No mound or bump shall be left to offset settlement.
(Code 1965, § 26-47)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 288/648
Sec. 29-115. Protection of public.
The holder of a permit to open a street, alley or parkway under this article shall be responsible for properly and adequately safeguarding
the public from all hazards caused by such an opening and excess materials therefrom until such opening has been safely and
satisfactorily closed. The holder of the permit shall install and maintain at all times adequate barricades and good and sufficient warning
lights around all openings and obstructions and shall, as soon as possible and without delay, backfill the trenches and restore the surface
of the street or alley to such condition that it will be safe for vehicular and pedestrian traffic. No excess material shall be spread over the
street or alley surface adjacent to trenches. The holder of the permit shall be responsible for the maintenance and safety of the backfilled
trench for a period of seventy-two (72) hours, excluding Sundays and holidays.
Where all or a part of an existing concrete sidewalk, driveway or curb and gutter has been damaged or destroyed in the course of
installing or repairing a private utility line, then the concrete surface shall be repaired and refinished by the holder of the permit as soon as
possible in such a manner as to meet the specifications of the city for such work.
(Code 1965, § 26-48)
Sec. 29-116. Work responsibilities.
(a) City to pave. The work of permanently repaving and resurfacing all excavations in paved streets or alleys under this section will be
done by the city; however, for major projects, the director of public works may authorize or require the permit holder to make such
repairs or contract this work to be done by a bonded paving contractor.
(b) Applicant may backfill and cleanup. The permit holder may elect to either accomplish all backfill, compaction, base repair and
cleanup himself or to have the city street department accomplish this work at the established rates. Permit fees will be computed on the
basis or work done by the city.
(Code 1965, § 26-49)
Sec. 29-117. Maintenance responsibility.
Permit holders shall be responsible for one year from the date of backfill for all defects in the work. Any settlement or grade changes
caused by failure to adequately compact the backfill shall be repaired by permit holder on notice from the city that failure has occurred. If
the permit holder fails to make the needed repairs within ten (10) days from notice, the city shall make such repairs; in this event, the
permit holder shall pay the repair cost upon receipt of bill from the city. Failure of the permit holder to pay any and all fees and charges
according to this section shall be cause for the city building inspection department to refuse any future permits until past due accounts are
paid.
No future charges will be made to the permit holder for failure of work originally done by city.
(Code 1965, § 26-49)
Secs. 29-118–29-128. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. HOUSE NUMBERS
Sec. 29-129. Required to be placed.
It shall be the duty of the owner of any house situated in the city to place or permit to be placed thereon in some conspicuous place on
such house an official street number, so that the number may be plainly seen and observed from the street. In case the owner is a
nonresident of the city it shall be the duty of the agent of the owner or the occupant of such house, when such agent or occupant is
notified by the building inspector, to place such official number on such house; provided, that such agent or occupant so notified shall be
allowed five (5) days' time from the date of the receipt of the notice to place such official number on such house.
(Code 1965, § 26-38)
Sec. 29-130. Numbering by city.
The city council may, if they deem it advisable, officially number the houses within the city and for such purpose may employ such
persons as they deem suitable to perform such work, and prescribe the compensation to be paid such persons. It shall be the duty of all
persons owning or occupying any house to permit such persons to freely enter thereon for the purpose of performing such work of
officially numbering any house.
(Code 1965, § 26-39)
Sec. 29-131. Charge for numbers when placed by city.
In case the city council determines to do the work of officially numbering houses in the city, the official numbers shall be furnished free
of charge, and it shall be unlawful for any person to charge any tenant, occupant or owner of any house compensation for any such
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 289/648
official number.
(Code 1965, § 26-40)
Sec. 29-132. Numbering method generally.
All houses shall be considered officially numbered when numbered in strict accordance and compliance with the terms of this article and
in accordance with the plant delineating and prescribing the method of numbering houses adopted and on file and of record in the office
of the building official.
(Code 1965, § 26-41)
Sec. 29-133. Obtaining correct number.
It shall be the duty of the building official, upon application, to give the proper number for houses to persons requesting the same. Such
persons shall be required to state the street upon which the house to be numbered is situated and the direction and distance the same is
situated from the nearest cross street.
(Code 1965, § 26-42)
Sec. 29-134. Altering, removal, etc., of numbers placed by city.
In the event the city council shall determine to do the work of officially numbering the houses within the city, each official number shall
be placed on each house in the manner provided by this article and it shall thereafter be unlawful for any person to willfully deface, injure
or remove any such number; provided, that a person shall have the right to remove such number when altering or changing the house and
then shall place such number temporarily at some other part of such house where it will show conspicuously from the street.
(Code 1965, § 26-42)
Sec. 29-135. Baselines.
The Texas and Pacific Railroad tracks shall be the base line for the purpose of numbering of houses for every street running north or south
or substantially in that course, and each street so running north or south shall, for the purpose of such numbering, have its beginning point
at the Texas and Pacific Railroad track. The numbering shall begin at such initial point with the number “100” increasing north or south
as the case may be, from such initial point to the city limits. Each street running east and west, or substantially with that course, shall have
its beginning point at the east line of the city limits. The numbering shall begin at such initial point with the number “0” increasing
westerly to the city limits.
(Code 1965, § 26-43)
Sec. 29-136. Assignment of numbers.
The odd numbers shall appear on the east side of streets running north and south, and the south side of streets running east and west. The
even numbers shall appear on the north side of streets running east and west, and on the west side of streets running north and south.
(Code 1965, § 26-43)
Sec. 29-137. Specifications for numbers.
The official number referred to in this article shall be at least three (3) inches high and composed of bright metal which will not tarnish or
corrode on account of the action of the elements (aluminum numbers are preferable); provided, that in case the city council should
determine to do the official numbering, then the official numbers shall be composed of such material and be of such size and character as
may be adopted by the city council. Nothing in this section shall prohibit any number from being painted by any person when such
character of material is used as will, in the judgment of the building official, be equal in strength, durability and service to the metal
number required. All such painted numbers shall be put in at the same time that the city council is placing the official numbers.
(Code 1965, § 26-44)
Secs. 29-138–29-148. Reserved.

The purpose of this article is to provide a method to permit the use of public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways in conjunction
with construction, alteration, renovation, demolition, repair and use of any building or structure on abutting property. (Ord. No. 86-1985,
pt. 1, 12-5-85)

Sec. 29-150. Permit required.
No person shall use any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public way or appropriate any portion thereof in conjunction with
construction, alteration, renovation, demolition, repair and use of any building or structure on abutting property without first obtaining a
permit from the city. (Ord. No. 86-1985, pt. 1, 12-5-85)
Sec. 29-151. Application.
All applications for a permit to use the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways as a construction staging area shall be made
to the director of building inspection. Such application shall be made on a form provided by the director of building inspection for that

Permit applicant (or permittee) shall prior to issuance of a permit, file with the department of building inspection a good and sufficient
surety bond issued by a corporate surety authorized by the State Board of Insurance to do business in the State of Texas in the principal
sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), made payable to the City of Abilene in guarantee of faithful performance of the conditions of
this article of the City Code. Said bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of one (1) year following the completion of the
project for which the permit will be issued. (Ord. No. 86-1985, pt. 1, 12-5-85)

ARTICLE IX. SPECIAL EVENTS LICENSE
Sec. 29-160. Purpose of article.
The purpose of this article is to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of the public at special events which utilize city rights-of-way by
creating a licensing process for these events.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-161. Definitions.
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section:
Business day. Any calendar day except Saturday, Sunday or any city holiday.
City licensing department. The department of the city responsible under the special event license policy for accepting applications for a
special events license. These departments include the police department and the department of public works.
City manager. The city manager of the City of Abilene or designee.
Official. City peace officers, the director of public works or designee, or the city manager or designee who administers, implements, or
enforces the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-162. License requirements and exemptions.
(a) Any event that utilizes city rights-of-way shall comply with the licensing requirements of the special event license policy adopted
by city council and kept on file with the police department and the department of public works.
(b) This article does not apply to events which require a street use license under article V of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-163. Application.
Applicants for special event licenses under this article must file with the applicable city licensing department an application in writing on
a form obtained from the city.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 291/648
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 26-164. Required fee.
(a) The fee for a special event license shall be determined from time to time and placed on file in the office of the city secretary. No
application for a license will be processed until the required fees are tendered to the city. The license fee is nonrefundable and shall not be
prorated.
(b) Expenses for any additional costs for city services necessary for the event shall be billed separately. These expenses include but are
not limited to costs for police escort, security, traffic control, refuse collection and street sweeping.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-165. Issuance.
Upon completion and presentation of the application, the city shall issue a license to the applicant within the timelines indicated in the
special event license policy.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-166. Expiration.
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire at the termination of the licensed event.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-167. Transfer.
No license issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferred or assigned.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-168. Denial.
An application for license may be denied to a person under this article for the following reasons.
(1) An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application.
(2) An official has determined that the health, safety or welfare of the citizens would be impaired by allowing the event to
occur as requested.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-169. Revocation.
(a) Licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked for any of the following causes by any official of the city:
(1) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license.
(2) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying out the licensed event.
(3) The applicant refuses to comply with the terms of the license.
(4) The applicant has not provided proof of insurance, if required.
(b) Notice of revocation of a license shall be given verbally or in writing, and specify the grounds of the revocation.
(c) When the applicant receives notice that their license has been revoked, they shall immediately surrender their license to the
revoking official.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-170. Appeals.
(a) An appeal from any act of denial or revocation of any license shall be filed with the city manager within five (5) business days from
the date of denial or revocation.
(b) Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city manager a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 292/648
(c) The city manager shall issue a decision on the denial or revocation in writing within 5 business days of receipt of the appeal.
(d) The revocation or denial is not stayed pending the city manager's decision.
(e) The decision and order of the city manager on such appeal shall be final and conclusive.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
Sec. 29-171. Penalty for violation.
Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, agent or employee thereof who violates any of the provisions of this article shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each
offense. Each and every hour that such violation shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 70-2013, pt. 1(Exh. A), 12-19-13)
